Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Winthrop University REU: Bridging Applied and Theoretical Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Winthrop University hosts a nine week research program, Winthrop University REU: Bridging Applied and Theoretical Mathematics. Research themes include differential equations modeling of cancer biology and the study of phylogenetics using algebraic geometry and combinatorics. A professional development seminar and a colloquium series supplement the faculty mentored research activities.

This program supports students from groups traditionally underrepresented in mathematics graduate programs, but welcomes all students from institutions whose highest mathematics degree is Bachelor's degree. This project builds a diverse and talented group of mathematics students and supports their transition into graduate programs in STEM fields. In this project, faculty mentors provide sustained mentorship beyond the completion of the nine week research experience and participants are supported to present their findings at national meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2014-2016 REU site at Winthrop University (WU) offered undergraduate students across the U.S. the opportunity to conduct original research on problems that bridged theoretical and applied mathematics. The goals of this program included: 1) providing transformative research training for WU-REU participants including appropriate professional development, 2) creating an environment in which participants make significant contributions to research projects and share their findings with regional and national audiences, and 3) increasing the number of participants who enroll in STEM graduate programs.

Each summer, two faculty mentors collaborated with eight students during the nine-week program. The program focused on serving students with limited access to undergraduate research opportunities at their home institution. Additionally, 21 of the 24 total participants came from groups traditionally underrepresented in mathematics graduate programs (including minorities, women, persons with disabilities, first-generation college students, low-income students, and military veterans). 
In teams of two or three, students worked on research problems spanning two general themes: 1) interactions between algebraic geometry, combinatorics and phylogenetics, and 2) interactions between differential equations and cancer biology. Faculty mentors ran short courses on necessary background material for each theme, assisted students with choosing problems appropriate for study at the undergraduate level, and worked collaboratively with students throughout the duration of the research experience to obtain meaningful mathematical results. 
In addition to working daily on their research project, students participated in several professional development activities during the nine-week program. Faculty members from Winthrop and other nearby institutions provided sessions on topics such as choosing a graduate program, writing personal statements, applying for nationally competitive awards, life as a graduate student, etc. Regional mathematicians also participated in colloquia to expose program participants to other areas of mathematical research. Each year, students visited a regional graduate program to interact with graduate students and faculty. A mini-symposium was also held each summer with other regional REU programs where students presented their summer work and shared research experiences. 
By the end of the nine weeks, all students left the program with a written report of their project, as well as a poster and oral presentation summarizing their research. Grant funds were allocated to support students’ travel to a national mathematics conference to present their summer work. In total, participants from the 2014-2016 WU-REU gave thirty presentations at regional and national conferences. Moreover, ten peer-reviewed journal articles at various stages in the publication process have resulted from the 2014-2016 WU-REU. 
The 2014-2016 REU program at Winthrop University provided 24 undergraduates with in-depth research training and professional development, and contributed new insights into original research problems bridging pure and applied mathematics.
